node.contents: I don't know why this this is a surprise. It's specified in the Javadoc.

astNode.text: I don't know why this this is a surprise. It's specified in the Javadoc.

node.contents: I wanted to create a very restrictive security manager, so I extended SecurityManager and overridden all the custom checkXXX methods.

astNode.text: I wanted to create a very restrictive security manager, so I extended SecurityManager and overridden all the custom checkXXX methods.

node.contents: But then I found out that my security manager is useless, because anyone can just:

astNode.text: But then I found out that my security manager is useless, because anyone can just:

elements.contents: @Override public void checkPermission(Permission perm) { if (perm.getName().equals("setSecurityManager")) { throw new SecurityException("You shall have no other security manager but me!"); } }

node.valueRep: "You shall have no other security manager but me!"

units.rawText: @Override public void checkPermission(Permission perm) { if (perm.getName().equals("setSecurityManager")) { throw new SecurityException("You shall have no other security manager but me!"); } }

node.contents: Are there any more surprises? Any other things I have to do to make my SecurityManager hermetic?

astNode.text: Are there any more surprises? Any other things I have to do to make my SecurityManager hermetic?

node.contents: 1. I tried this: systemSecurityField = java.lang.Class.forName("java.lang.System").getDeclaredField("security"); but got java.lang.NoSuchFieldException: security

astNode.text: 1. I tried this: systemSecurityField = java.lang.Class.forName("java.lang.System").getDeclaredField("security"); but got java.lang.NoSuchFieldException: security

node.contents: Strange, it works for me (using Java 6, update 24). Using: `System.class.getDeclaredField("security");`

astNode.text: Strange, it works for me (using Java 6, update 24). Using: `System.class.getDeclaredField("security");`

node.contents: There are at least a couple of things I can think of:

astNode.text: There are at least a couple of things I can think of:

node.contents:
1. Someone could use reflection to set the System.security field to accessible, and then set it to whatever they want.

  2. Someone could use sun.misc.Unsafe to directly overwrite your instance in memory with whatever random thing they want.

astNode.text:
1. Someone could use reflection to set the System.security field to accessible, and then set it to whatever they want.

  2. Someone could use sun.misc.Unsafe to directly overwrite your instance in memory with whatever random thing they want.

node.contents: I think your SecurityManager can guard against these things, since they both rely on calls to Field.setAccessible(). But better to test it out to make sure.

astNode.text: I think your SecurityManager can guard against these things, since they both rely on calls to Field.setAccessible(). But better to test it out to make sure.
